field_reports.description:
At 6 AM, the central region of the Tropical Storm was estimated at 17.3°N latitude and 77.8°W longitude, placing it about 160 kilometers southwest of Kingston, Jamaica, 405 kilometers southeast of Grand Cayman Island, and 670 kilometers southeast of Punta del Este, Isla de la Juventud. It is moving in a northwestern direction at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour.
In the next 12 to 24 hours, this system is expected to continue moving in a similar direction and speed, approaching Jamaica. As it progresses, it will continue to gain organization and intensity and could reach hurricane status near the Cayman Islands. Rain, showers, and thunderstorms will persist in the eastern and central regions, with the potential for strong and intense conditions in some areas. Precipitation will subsequently extend to western Cuba. The effects of wind and sea in different regions of the country will depend on the trajectory and intensity of this tropical cyclone.   The following provinces in Cuba are currently under alert due to the conditions associated with Tropical Storm Rafael: Camagüey, Ciego de Ávila, Sancti Spíritus, Cienfuegos, Villa Clara, Matanzas, Mayabeque, Artemisa, La Habana, and Pinar del Río. Additionally, the special municipality of Isla de la Juventud is also included in this alert. These areas are being monitored closely as they may experience significant weather impacts, including heavy rainfall, strong winds, and potential flooding.

The south-eastern Bahamas was placed under a hurricane warning as Hurricane Oscar, a Category 1 storm, approached the region. The island of Inagua was hit hardest when Oscar made landfall on Sunday, October 20, with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph. Residents of Matthew Town, Inagua, experienced heavy rainfall, thunderstorms, and significant flooding in certain areas.

Following an assessment by the Emergency Operations Centre (EOC), officials reported that several homes suffered extensive roof damage, while others experienced minor damage, such as missing shingles. Flooding was also reported, with water entering some homes. However, by the time of this report, over 90% of the island's electricity had been restored, and residents had access to clean drinking water.

After passing through Inagua, Hurricane Oscar veered east toward Cuba, but later looped back through the south-eastern Bahamas as a tropical storm. A tropical storm warning remained in effect for the central and south-eastern Bahamas until Tuesday 22 October 2024. Residents of Crooked Island, Long Cay, Mayaguana, and Ragged Island reported increased wind gusts and heavy rain, but no significant property damage or fatalities.

The Disaster Risk Management Authority (DRM) issued the "All Clear" at 2:00 p.m. on October 22, 2024, and shelters in Inagua were deactivated by 4:00 p.m. Thirteen residents of Inagua, who had evacuated to the hurricane shelter out of caution, returned home safely. Fortunately, no injuries or fatalities were reported during the storm.

A Royal Bahamas Defence Force vessel is en route to Inagua with essential supplies to aid in the island's recovery efforts.

At 2 p.m. on Saturday, October 19, 2024, a hurricane warning was issued for the Southeast Bahamas, including the islands of Mayaguana, Inagua, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, and Ragged Island. Hurricane Oscar is moving west at 12 MPH, with maximum sustained winds of 80 MPH and higher gusts. Hurricane-force winds extend up to 5 miles from the center, and tropical storm-force winds extend up to 45 miles. The Bahamas Red Cross group leaders and volunteers on the affected islands have met with District Councils and Family Island Administrators to review and activate emergency plans. All shelters in the Southeastern islands have been opened, and the Royal Bahamas Defence Force stationed on Ragged Island will also be assisting at their shelter.  Residents are securing their property and making necessary preparations to protect their families and livelihoods.

results.name: BHS: Cyclone - 10-2024 - Hurricane Oscar
results.summary: At 2 p.m. on Saturday, October 19, 2024, a hurricane warning was issued for the Southeast Bahamas, including the islands of Mayaguana, Inagua, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, and Ragged Island. Hurricane Oscar is moving west at 12 MPH, with maximum sustained winds of 80 MPH and higher gusts. Hurricane-force winds extend up to 5 miles from the center, and tropical storm-force winds extend up to 45 miles. The Bahamas Red Cross group leaders and volunteers on the affected islands have met with District Councils and Family Island Administrators to review and activate emergency plans. All shelters in the Southeastern islands have been opened, and the Royal Bahamas Defence Force stationed on Ragged Island will also be assisting at their shelter.  Residents are securing their property and making necessary preparations to protect their families and livelihoods.

field_reports.description:
The recent update on Tropical Storm Nicole is positioned 140 miles ENE of Hope Town Abaco, 195 miles ENE of East End Grand Bahama and 210 miles NE of New Providence moving at 10 MPH traveling in a West-Northwest with a Westward motion. Hurricane Warnings have been issued for the island of Grand Bahama, Abaco, Bimini and the Berry Islands. 

The Emergency Operating Centers have been activated on the Northern Islands with shelters opened from 9 am this morning. The following is the breakdown of the number of shelters and the individuals who have sought refuge in these facilities:

Abaco Island :
Shelter count active  - 12
Admissions - 157
60 Males
43 females
23 girls
25 boys
5 babies
1 disable person
 
Grand Bahama:
Shelter count active -  10 
Admissions:
2 person (1 male 1 female )
15 person (7 females 4 boys 5 girls 3 males)
2 males
 
Eleuthera Island :
Shelter Count active : 8
Admission: Nil
 
New Providence:
Shelters Active : Nil
Admission: Nil
 
Andros Island
Shelters Active: Nil
Admission: Nil
 
Evacuations:
Guana Cay - 25 total evacuees to Abaco mainland

field_reports.description:
As of November 9th at 5pm when NEMA (National Emergency Management Agency) conducted the necessary personnel from various Government Agencies. With Tropical Storm Nicole making an its westward trek towards the Northern Bahamas with Alert #21 being issued by the Bahamas Department of Meteorology with it being 50 miles E of Freeport, Grand Bahama, 105 miles N-NW of New Providence and 100 miles NE of Alice Town, Bimini. The Bahamas Government has given an all clear on the Tropical Storm Warnings for the islands of Berry Islands, New Providence, Eleuthera and Andros, however, Abaco, Grand Bahama and Bimini still remain under a Hurricane Watch. 
 
There were 27 shelters activated between the islands of Grand Bahama, Abaco and Bimini, where 520 persons seeked shelter. The team leader for the Abaco reported there was no loss of life and they are still experiencing Tropical storm conditions and have been informed that people should not venture out until an all clear has been issued.
field_reports.summary: BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - Bahamas - Hurricane Nicole Update -03-(11-09-2022)

field_reports.description:
As of November 7th, 2022 the following NS Brief was developed to report on the exposure and impact of Sub-Tropical Storm Nicole which has formed northeast of the Bahamas. Presently islands in the north west of The Bahamas Archipelago are subject to experience Tropical Storm and Hurricane conditions emanating from this system. The islands Of Grand Bahama, Abaco, Bimini, Berry Island, Eleuthera, New Providence and Andros can be impacted if the hurricane projected path shifts North West.

The center of SubTropical Storm Nicole is approximately 420 miles E of Hope Town, 480 miles E of East End, Grand Bahama, 390 miles E-N of Governors Harbour and 455 miles E-N of New Providence.

Nicole is moving toward the NW near 9 MPH with maximum sustained winds are near 45 MPH with higher gusts. Gradual strengthening is forecast  during the next few days and Nicole is forecast to be at Hurricane intensity by Wednesday or Wednesday Night while it is moving near or over the Northwest Bahamas. 
 
The NS is in contact with NEMA and Team Leaders in each of the islands aforementioned above and the NS volunteers have been engaged accordingly.
field_reports.summary: BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - Bahamas - SubTropical Storm Nicole Update -01-(11-07-2022)

results.name: BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - BHS: Cyclone - 2022-11 - Bahamas - SubTropical Storm Nicole Update -01-(11-07-2022)

field_reports.description:
As of September 20, 2022 the following “Situational Report” was developed to report on the exposure and impact of Hurricane Fiona to the Bahamas Red Cross National Society. Presently the most southerly islands in the Bahamas Archipelago are subject to experiencing Tropical Storm conditions emanating from the Hurricane. The islands Of Mayaguana, Crooked Island, Acklins, Inagua, Ragged Island, Long Cay and Samana Cay remain under active watch in the event weather conditions deteriorate with respect to the hurricane projected path shifting North West. 
The National Society is in contact with NEMA and team leaders and volunteers on each of the islands aforementioned above have been engaged accordingly. 

Evacuation: 
Evacuation was done on the island of Mayaguana at 8am, September 20, 2022 with approx. 12 elderly and vulnerable residents. Evacuees were relocated to the island of Exuma.  

Shelter Management: 
Four shelters were activated as of 8am, September 20, 2022.  
One on the Island of Mayaguana  
One on the island of Exuma to house the evacuees from Mayaguana 
Two on the island of Crooked Island 

BRCS Team leaders and volunteers on each of the islands where shelters were activated are providing assistance with shelter management. Registering of person entering Shelter and food distribution 
 
Population densities for each Island: 
Mayaguana – 210 
Acklins -600 
Crooked Island -300 
Ragged Island – 120 
Inagua – 1000 
Long Cay – 20 
Samana Cay 20 

Inventory: 
BRCS Inventory in New Providence can disburse approximately 400 NFI’s
field_reports.summary: BHS: Cyclone - 2022-09 -  The Bahamas- Hurricane Fiona Update- #02- 20/09/2022

countries.society_name: Saint Kitts and Nevis Red Cross Society
countries.name: Saint Kitts and Nevis

field_reports.description:
As Tropical Storm Fiona made its passage across the Eastern Caribbean. St. Kitts and Nevis began feeling the effects of this system early Friday morning 16th September with intermittent showers that grew in intensity throughtout the day. The bulk of Tropical Storm Fiona Passed to the south of St. Kitts Nevis about 2:00am Saturday morning dumping plenty rain and gusty winds. At this time, there are no reports of major damages. A flash flood warning remain in effect as the soil is alread satuated from previous systems, and Fiona is expected to dump an addutional 2 - 6 inches of rains. A more detail assessment will be conducted later when the rains subsides. Volunteers were placed on alert since September 14th after a national prestrike meeting at NEMA.

Volunteers in the Sandy Point District discovered our preposition storage container had signicant leaks due to recent and heavy rains. The leaks took place in the area of the two extractor fans and a few bad spots on the roof of the container. Most of the floor area was wet but most of the stocks were protected on pallets. The stock damage were limited to 10 cases kitchen sets and  and 1 bale x 50 blankets. An assessment of the Dieppe Bay storage container will be conducted to determine if the situation is simular. This issue was brought to the attention to IFRC via a DM meeting on september 16th and 17th 2022.

Trevor Seaton, Disaster Coordinator

SKNRCS

BRCS remains in preparedness mode as of September 16, 2022. The NS volunteers in New Providence and the major family islands have been engaged and were advised to ensure an established communication is secured with the Local Island Administrator (Government Authoritative Head responsible for Governments Administration in the Surrounding Islands).

 

The NS has contacted NEMA and advised the Agency The NS is available and remains in preparedness mode and will respond in line with our Terms Of Reference with their Agency under Emergency Support Functions #6 and #13 if The NEOC is activated. 

 

Next week Monday and Tuesday, Sept 19-20  will be key assessment dates for The Bahamas and the NS as the projected path of TS Fiona will be more definitive as it relates to its potential impact to The Bahamas."

 

Warehouse Inventory:

 

Warehouse Stocks accounts for 400 NFI's if needed for disbursement.
field_reports.summary: BHS: Cyclone - 2022-09 - Bahamas - Tropical Storm Fiona Update -01-(9-16-2022)

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The present month saw continued changes by the Bahamas Government to lessen the previous restrictions on Covid-19 rules. Resulting in increased travel, school being fully opened, hotel bookings seeing better numbers than the previous month or even year. One of the immediate changes was the lifting of the 5 day test requirement for visitors entering the country. Comments came from the President of the Bahamas Hotel and Tourism Association (BHTA) Mr. Robert Sands, “This is absolutely another firm step in the right direction, particularly at this critical juncture in the recovery of our tourism industry,” said Sands.

The Covid-19 numbers continue to decrease well into the single digits for hospital admissions and deaths. This positive sign has the government and many residents feeling optimistic about the economy and life getting back to some "normalcy" . However, there is still an air of caution with residents and the wearing of face masks is still required. Persons traveling interisland are not required to take a Covid-19 test any longer. More sites for Vaccination and booster shots are now available with extended times and days for residents to take advantage of. 

As of March 2022 the latest numbers on the vaccinated the total number of vaccinated reached 334,181 (total doses), 153,552 (one dose excluding J&J), and 163,526 (Fully vaccinated including J&J). The number continues to remain stagnant and the goal is to bring back an urgency so that residents see the importance of getting it done.
field_reports.notes_health:
The Ambulance service continues to be a great strength of the BRCS and the continued partnership with the Public Hospital Authority (PHA) and for the month of March the use of the vehicles to transport patients was done. Other activities that involved the use of the Ambulances were the National  Mass Casualty Incident Drill that involved other governmental and non-government organizations where a simulation was conducted on Abaco, Bimini, Eleuthera, Grand Bahama and Inagua. A total of 11 volunteers participated with 4 males and 7 females and the feedback about the team was positive. 

Also in March the use of the vehicles for the BAISS (The Bahamas Association of Independent Secondary Schools) hosted two days of track meets and some 7 volunteers made up of 2 males and 5 females. The final use for the month was with the Golden Wings Association and only two volunteers assisted. 

Another turn around for the BRCS is the increase in First Aid classes and participants. Since the decrease in Covid-19 cases, more companies are either doing the 2 year renewal or signing up for the first time. For the month a total of 48 persons participated with 17 males, 29 females, 2 unknown and out of those numbers 7 were volunteers.
field_reports.description:
Describe the primary and secondary effects on the health system and affected population.
 
Additional doctors were acquired from Cuba for the assistance of medical treatment in the hospital to provide continued work. The strengthening of the capacity within the Ministry of Health means it helps with the improvement in medical care. With the decrease in Covid-19 numbers the hospital continues to put measures in place for visitors to have a limited time to see relatives. Some of the positive effects are non-emergency surgeries have resumed and Non Covid-19 treatment being treated. For the most part, Covid-19 protocols are still being enforced with the sanitizing of hands, the wearing of masks and social distance keeping 6 ft apart. 

The BRCS continues to be active in supporting the PHA (Public Hospital Authority), with the loss of one vehicle being serviced, limited service was provided. Support continues with having volunteers and staff assist at vaccination sites on the island of Abaco and Grand Bahama by working the registration desk or providing transportation for the elderly and disable.

The latest reports by the  Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in March 2022, downgraded the Bahamas from a level 4 (very high) to a level 2 (low) for its Travel Risk Advisory Rating. This information was shared by the Minister of Health and Wellness during a press conference during that month. Such a change means that travelers are encouraged to be up to date with their vaccinations and there is still a risk of contracting the virus.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The present state of the country amidst Covid-19 is one of great transition for the nation. With the numbers decreasing and people feeling more free to move about, many are lobbying for the Government to dissolve the law of wearing masks in public. However, some things 
That was set to change as the return of students face to face. During the month schools reopened with the same Covid-19 guidelines in place such as wearing masks, washing/sanitizing your hands and keeping 6 ft apart. The Government hopes that this would bring a sense of normalcy to the educational system and have students back in the classroom seeing that many were not showing up virtually. 

For the month the number of Covid-19 confirmed cases was 37,052, the newly confirmed cases for the week ending August 27th zero, and the number of deaths 823. As of the 20th of August there were for the  vaccine total doses confirmed 359,269, people who have received one dose 160,606, and people fully vaccinated (including J&J). With a decline in positive cases so is the amount of people going out to get the jab. The numbers continue to remain low in the single digits resulting in less persons taking the shot. Also the ambulance services have been dissolved and no longer assist with Covid-19 transportation. Instead Ambulance services are mainly for events hosted by various organizations, thereby generating income for the National Society.

Prior to the beginning of the school year the Minister of Health and Wellness encouraged parents to have their children vaccinated. Especially, with new vaccines coming in for children under the age of 5. Since the opening of school there have been no reported cases of Covid-19 on campuses which has been a relief for students, teachers, parents and the government.
field_reports.description:
The Princess Margaret Hospital is still on the rebound since the pandemic and is dealing with the challenges of having more space in the already packed facility. Addressing the backlog of surgeries and providing more beds has become the priority of the government. Along with disposing of the faulty equipment in the operating rooms.

With three out of 8 wards not available  the bed capacity has diminished considerably making this a crisis situation for the Ministry. Repairs could not be carried out during the pandemic and funds had to be diverted so this caused a delay on any work being done.

results.name: BHS: Epidemic - 2022-03 -  The Bahamas- Epidemic: 08-15-2022
results.summary:
The Princess Margaret Hospital is still on the rebound since the pandemic and is dealing with the challenges of having more space in the already packed facility. Addressing the backlog of surgeries and providing more beds has become the priority of the government. Along with disposing of the faulty equipment in the operating rooms.

With three out of 8 wards not available  the bed capacity has diminished considerably making this a crisis situation for the Ministry. Repairs could not be carried out during the pandemic and funds had to be diverted so this caused a delay on any work being done.

field_reports.description:
With Covid-19 cases continuing to be on a decline there is only one island that reported a positive case in Eleuthera outside of New Providence, the capital. So we can see the amount of new cases remain low but the government has discontinued all mandatory Covid-19 protocols. This means that people are free to move about without masks and keeping 6 ft apart. However, there are some residents who despite the lifted restrictions still cover their nose and mouth along with keeping their distance. Residents are allowed to take free tests at various locations throughout the Bahamas, making it easier for the government to track the number of cases. 

As it relates to the Covid 19 vaccine tracker a total of 364,421 doses were administered, 162, 321 accounts for 1 dose excluding the J&J, and 173,380 represent people fully vaccinated including the J&J. The numbers did increase with a total of 1,769 persons that took the vaccine with the numbers not as robust as it was during the peak of Covid-19. There are sites throughout the Bahamas where people can easily get vaccinated, and the hours are more accessible hours.

results.name: BHS: Epidemic - 2022-03 -  The Bahamas- Epidemic: 10-15-2022

results.name: GDACS Orange: Guadeloupe, Antigua and Barbuda, Montserrat, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Virgin Islands ...
results.summary: From 13/08/2021 to 13/08/2021, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 83 km/h) SEVEN-21 was active in Atlantic. The cyclone affects these countries: Guadeloupe, Antigua and Barbuda, Montserrat, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Virgin Islands  U.S., Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Bahamas, Cuba (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.

field_reports.description: A Tropical Storm Watch is in effect for South Eastern Bahamas including Acklins, Crooked Island & Long Cay, Inagua, Ragged Island, Mayaguana and Samana Cay. Expected impact would be flooding resulting from 1-3 inches of rainfall and isolated incidents of up to 5 inches rainfall. Potential population affected 2,181. NEMA has partially activated an EOC for named islands. We are continuing to monitor the conditions. Government managed shelters have been placed on standby on each of those islands. The BRCS leaders on the affected islands are on alert and are engaging with the Disaster Management Unit (DMU) at Headquarters located in the northwestern district, New Providence.
field_reports.summary: Bahamas - Tropical Depression Fred  Situation Update -01-(8-12-2021)

results.name: Bahamas - Tropical Depression Fred  Situation Update -01-(8-12-2021)

field_reports.description:
Tropical Storm Eta was last reported at 8 pm by the Department of Meteorology, Saturday 7 November, 2020. Currently a Tropical Storm warning remains in effect for the Northwest Bahamas, which includes the islands of Grand Bahama, Abaco, Bimini, Berry Islands, Andros, New Providence and Eleuthera. These islands can expect Tropical Storm conditions within the next 36 hours. There is a Tropical Storm alert for the Central Bahamas including islands Exuma and the Cays, Cat Island, Long Island, San Salvador and Rum Cay. Present course has TS Eta moving 165 miles West- Southwest of Camaguey Cuba or about 375 miles south of Miami, Florida or about 310 miles Southwest of Kemps Bay Andros or about 385 Southwest of New Providence.

Moving at 14 MPH (22 KM/H) is expected to move Northeast with a gradual turn toward the North and Northwest. With maximum sustained winds at 65 MPH (95 KM/H) and there is expected to be an increase in strength as it moves West of the Northwest Bahamas as it approaches Florida.
